ItemField.Value: The Women of Barmer are the skilled artisans who create the beautiful appliqued and embroidered accessories and home textiles available through Tilonia.com and the Tilonia Craft Shop of the Barefoot College. The calendar includes a series of portraits of these women of western Rajasthan. The Barefoot College helps these women earn an income from their needlework by marketing these craft products in India and around the world.

Friends of Tilonia, Inc. is a US-based, 501(c)3 non-profit organization established to provide marketing and business development assistance to the crafts section of the Barefoot College, in Tilonia, Rajasthan, India. For more than 35 years, the Barefoot College has been working to address basic needs of the rural poor: water, health, education, energy and employment, while enrolling individuals in the processes that govern their lives.

In 1975, the lack of employment in the villages in Rajasthan forced many of the rural poor to migrate to the cities. While largely an agricultural area, many of the poor in the region were artisans engaged in various crafts. Lacking access to a broader market, these rural artisans abandoned, and still continue today to abandon their trades to seek other, more gainful means of livelihood.

The Barefoot College began promoting rural craft production to address this problem of under-employment. Assistance in improving designs and techniques, creation of marketing outlets, and access to credit have helped to restore and create new income opportunities for craftsmen and women. Training and materials provided by the College also enables women to work from home, helping them to generate income from their needlework or other handicrafts.

These rural artisans produce clothing and accessories, decorative home furnishings, furniture, rugs, textiles, handmade paper products, puppets and other toys, metalwork, and leather goods. The crafts are currently sold through retail shops and other outlets in India, Europe and Canada, generating $ 250,000 in income for more than 400 rural artisans in 50 villages who market their crafts inconjunction with the College. The College has participated in international trade shows and other market development efforts with support from national and international sponsors including Government of India, All India Handicrafts Board, UNESCO, Plan International, Bridgehead, Oxfam-Canada, and Traidcraft.

Friends of Tilonia is working with the College to develop direct sales and marketing channels for these crafts in the U.S. To support this effort, FOT has developed the online craftstore, www.tilonia.com, and is initiating sales promotion and direct marketing to wholesalers and distributors, and participating on behalf of the Barefoot College at selected US trade shows.

For more information, please contact:

Ellen Fish

You can help support the rural artisans of Tilonia in many ways:

 Buy Tilonia Crafts

Visit our online store and select items for your house, gifts for your friends and families, or start your holiday shopping early.

 Tell Your Friends

Let your friends know about our online store and tell them about the work of the Barefoot College.

 Become a Friend

You can help provide financial support to Friends of Tilonia. Your support will help FOT to train and support staff of the Barefoot College to manage the store via the Internet, and expand sales efforts in the U.S. through operation of the online store and other sales and marketing activities.

Contribute >>

 Become an Associate

Volunteers and business interns work with FOT's board of directors in developing FOT initiatives. The board includes seasoned business professionals with expertise in non-profit management, new product development, marketing, sales management, accounting and finance, business start-ups, and public and private sector fundraising.

 Become a Retail or Design Affiliate

Please contact us at shop@tilonia.com if you are interested in helping expand the craft sales of the rural artisans of India. We are looking for sales and distribution of our line of handcrafted products.

Biddam Devi cuts blockprint fabric for applique in the production center in Tilonia. An experienced seamstress, Biddam has more than 20 years experience producing Tilonia handcrafted appliques.


Sewing Tilonia Applique
Applique

Barmer applique was traditionally sewn on bedspreads of black or brown bases. Motifs were almost entirely inspired by nature: trees, leaves, flowers and animals. Women in six villages in Rajasthan produce these appliques. An elaborate bedspread may take nearly a month to complete.

Tilonia applique, the style of applique taught to women by the Barefoot College, uses designs adapted from mandanas which are traditional patterns on floors in Rajasthan. Abstract motifs are cut from fabrics and then stitched onto the base.
Artisans of Tilonia

Tilonia, a small village in the desert regions of Rajasthan, India, is home of the Barefoot College. For more than 35 years, the College has worked to improve the lives of the rural poor by addressing basic needs for water, electricity, housing, health, education and income. Tilonia helps these rural artisans to market their products in India and around the world. With new markets for their crafts, their livelihood is improved and the production of the traditional crafts is continued.

The Tilonia Home collection of home textiles features a variety of decorative pillows, bedspreads, quilts and duvet covers suitable for contemporary decorative styles while still reflective of Indian craft traditions. Tilonia Home brings the color and spice of India to your home.

The Tilonia Artisan collection of gifts and accessories offers handcrafted scarves and shawls, appliqued and quilted bags, handmade paper books, and colorful decorative items for the home. From the deserts of Rajasthan to the mountains of the Himalayas, Tilonia Artisan spans the cultures and traditions of India.

Avani is working with more than 475 artisans in over 40 villages in the Kumaon region of the Himalayas. Though both men and women are involved in this activity, the focus is largely on women where 85 per cent of the participants of this program are women. The artisan's collective has been registered as the Kumaon Earthcraft Self Reliant Cooperative.

Avani is a voluntary organization based in the Kumaon region of the Himalayas in northern India. Avani provides employment and educational opportunities to over 475 artisans in these remote mountain villages. The artisans use wild silk, Tibetan sheep wool and natural dyes to produce elegant, handloomed Avani textiles.

Avani is a voluntary organization working in the middle ranges of the Himalayas in Uttaranchal innorthern India.

Established in 1997 as the Kumaon branch of the Social Work and Research Center, also known as the Barefoot College, Avani was formally registered in 1999 as an independent organization operating with these "barefoot" principles of community-based, sustainable development.

Avani aims at the creation of village-based livelihood opportunities utilizing appropriate technologies like solar energy for household lighting systems, rain water harvesting systems for drinking water, eco-friendly initiatives such as organic farming and environmental education, and the introduction of seri-culture for production of wild silk yarns and textiles.

Visit Avani on YouTube


Avani Philosophy



UNESCO Seal of Excellence

Handloomed from naturally dyed, handspun yarns, Avani shawls have received the UNESCO Seal of Excellence in 2006 and 2007.

Tilonia, a small village in the desert regions of Rajasthan, is home of the Barefoot College.
Barefoot College

Since 1972, the Barefoot College has worked to improve the lives of the rural poor. The College addresses basic needs for water, electricity, housing, health, education and income.

Semi-literate women and men from nine countries around the world are currently training at the Barefoot College in Tilonia, Rajasthan, India to become barefoot solar engineers. After six months of training, these women and men will return to their own countries and solar-electrify their own communities.

You can learn more about the College's community-based development work through this collection of Barefoot College books and films.

Barefoot Photographers of Tilonia, photography books, sustainable development, Barefoot College, rural development, Tilonia

Barefoot Photographers of Tilonia is a colorful history of the Barefoot College of Tilonia, Rajasthan, India. The Barefoot College began in 1972 with the conviction that solutions to rural problems lie within the community. A visual treat, this full color, 145 page book presents photographs selected from a 120,000 picture archive of the Barefoot College

Taken by men and women who were untrained in photography, with no formal degrees or high-tech cameras, these images tell the story of the college's incredible journey. The photographs are accompanied by captions and stories from the people of Tilonia.

Today, more than 70 Pre-School Education Centers are coordinated by the Barefoot College and attended by more than 7,500 children with the help of 130 women Barefoot Teachers. Children from the ages of 1 to 5 are involved in the process of "Learning Readiness" and those that attend the pre-school education centers are provided with supplementary nutrition including milk, cereal and vegetables.

Your contribution of $100 supports one child in pre-school for one year and covers the costs of teacher training, supplementary nutrition, health check-ups, learning activities and school supplies.

The success of the "barefoot" approach is based on community commitment. Before solar electrification of the village, the whole village must agree to pay a monthly contribution for the repair and maintenance of the solar power, and to select the poorest, semi-literate, unemployable person who has roots in the village to be trained as a barefoot solar engineer.

You will help the Barefoot College to train barefoot solar engineers to solar-electrify their villages in India, Afghanistan, Bhutan, Bolivia, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Mali, Mauritania, Sierra Leone and The Gambia.
Barefoot College movies, DVDs, Barefoot Solar Engineers, solar power, rural development, sustainable development documentaries, Barefoot College of Tilonia

This short film documents the journey of 34 men and women from Ethiopia who travel to the Barefoot College of Tilonia in India to become "Barefoot" solar engineers. For 6 months, these engineering students work side by side with their India counter-parts, mastering the technology needed to assemble and maintain solar power systems, or build rooftop rainwater harvesting. With the technology de-mystified, they return to Ethiopia to solar electrify their own communities.

Today, this collaboration and partnership between poor communities, international agencies and governments is enabling more communities in Ethiopia and the rest of Africa to train barefoot professionals who develop their own communities.

Barefoot Solar Engineers of Ethiopia was produced by the Barefoot College and Roughcut Productions with support from a Skoll Foundation grant.
(DVD, 20 minutes, 2006) Visit the Barefoot College website to learn more about barefoot sustainable development >

Blockprinting is an ancient tradition -- evidence has been found of block printed fabrics dating back to 2000 BC. Today, it is a skill practiced in Rajasthan, a revival due to efforts by Anokhi and others passionate about this cultural tradition.

Tilonia sources block print fabrics in Bagru from two brothers, Hanuman and Ganesh. Each one runs a blocking printing business using traditional dyes and handcarved blocks.
Indian Block Print Textiles
block print, indian print, block printing, bedding, bedspread, bedspreads, bed linens

The villages of Bagru and Sanganer are well known in Rajasthan for their block printed fabrics. Over 200 families in Bagru produce block printed fabric. Traditional dyes are vegetable-based and produce red, black and indigo patterns on unbleached cotton fabric. More recently AZO free chemical dyes have been used to produce a wider range of color. Block printed fabrics are used to make a range of Tilonia home furnishings, kitchen and beach gear. They can also be ordered by the yard for your own sewing projects.
block print, indian print, block printing, bedding, bedspread, bedspreads, bed linens

Village Education Committees

The Night Schools of Tilonia are administered by the Village Education Committees. Each Committee has an average membership of 15-30 villagers including 5-10 women. The Committees have their bank accounts at the nearest rural bank. Two of its members along with one member from the College staff operate bank accounts. The Committees are responsible for day-to-day administration of the 250 night schools, purchase of teaching/learning material, repairs and maintenance of night school buildings and disbursement of honorariums to night school teachers.

Children's Parliament

The Children's Parliament controls and supervises the night schools. It is based on the belief that giving power to the people who have a vested interest in the school is the best way of ensuring its success -- as well as making the children aware of political structure and processes.

The Children's Parliament since its inception in 1993, has had five terms of office. The Parliament has elected representatives from night schools, situated in four districts of Rajasthan, covering a geographical outspread of 700-800 square kilometres, from semi-arid to the desert regions.

Most of the Prime Ministers have been girls, simply because more girls attend the Night Schools than boys.

Meet Bhagchand Dev, one of the former Prime Ministers of the Children's Parliament >

The Night Schools of the Barefoot College expose rural children to the concept of democracy and the importance of elections, citizenship and leadership. Every 3 years, 4000 night school children between the ages of 6 to 14 elect a Prime Minister and a Cabinet of Ministers. For over a decade, the 150 night schools have been jointly managed, supervised and administered by a children's parliament and the village education committee.

You will help support the Children's Parliament.

We help to support to the rural development programs of the Barefoot College and its charitable affiliates in India.

The Barefoot College addresses basic human needs of the poorest of poor through a community-based strategy, training semi-literate women and men who make less than $1 per day as Barefoot professionals. These professional work with their communities to:

  • Build and maintain rainwater harvesting systems for clean drinking water, and solar power systems for lighting and cooking
  • Provide preventative health services to tackle malaria, tuberculosis, AIDs and water-borne diseases
  • Construct geodesic domes for housing, night schools and community centers
  • Create opportunities for employment by marketing of artisan-made products
  • Empower women by training them to become barefoot solar and water engineers
  • Protect the environment by reducing the need for fossil fuels, conserving rainwater and reclaiming wasteland
By expanding sales of Tilonia crafts, we help to increase incomes earned by rural artisans and build economic opportunities in these rural communities.

Embroidery

Embroidery is traditionally a skill of the women of the Sind area in Pakistan, but is now found in Barmer, Kutch and parts of Bikaner. Elaborately embroidered items were given to a girl at the time of her marriage. Each of her blouses (kanchili) was embroidered by her mother. The Barefoot College, began working in the Barmer district in 1988 in an attempt to pay fair wages, develop new designs and preserve the craft. Today, the College helps market the embroidery of 150 women.

Barefoot College movies, DVDs, Global Rainwater Harvesting Collective, Barefoot Rooftop Rainwater Harvesting, Every Drop Counts, rural development, sustainable development documentaries, Barefoot College of Tilonia

Ten short videos on rooftop rainwater harvesting in schools illustrate how traditional knowledge of collecting and storing rainwater can be applied today to provide clean water for drinking and sanitation.

Water is one of the most basic human needs. Yet, about 1.1 billion people worldwide have inadequate water supplies, and a further 2.4 billion have no improved sanitation. One of the UN Millenium Development Goals is to reduce by half the proportion of people without access to safe drinking water by 2015.

To address this issue of access to water, the Global Rainwater Harvesting Collective advocates paying attention to centuries old traditions of collecting rainwater to meet daily needs for water, and leveraging traditional knowledge as the only long-term, cost-effective solution of providing water for drinking and sanitation in the hills, deserts, and neglected areas where remote, rural schools have no water.

Ten short videos on rooftop rainwater harvesting in schools illustrate how traditional knowledge of collecting and storing rainwater can be applied today to provide clean water for drinking and sanitation. Water is one of the most basic human needs. Yet, about 1.1 billion people worldwide have inadequate water supplies, and a further 2.4 billion have no improved sanitation. One of the UN Millenium Development Goals is to reduce by half the proportion of people without access to safe drinking water by 2015. To address this issue of access to water, the Global Rainwater Harvesting Collective advocates paying attention to centuries old traditions of collecting rainwater to meet daily needs for water, and leveraging traditional knowledge as the only long-term, cost-effective solution of providing water for drinking and sanitation in the hills, deserts, and neglected areas where remote, rural schools have no water.

Friends of Tilonia

Friends of Tilonia, Inc. is a US-based, tax-exempt, 501(c)3 non-profit organization helping to support the income-generating programs of the Barefoot College in Tilonia, Rajasthan, India.

Your contribution as a Friend of Tilonia helps us to build support for the Barefoot College and its barefoot model for development. Due to the support of our sponsors, 100% of your contribution will fund Barefoot College initiatives. We also welcome in-kind contributions. Please contact ellen@tilonia.com if you would like to volunteer or contribute other services.
bedding, duvet covers, duvet sets, queen duvet, bed linens

A young Rajasthani girl attends the festival for International Women's Day.

Girls especially benefit from the Barefoot College's development programs. Nearly 70% of rural children in India do not have time to go to school during the day. They work collecting drinking water, fetching firewood, or tending animals and other essential domestic work for their families.

The Barefoot College began Night Schools for these children in 1975 to provide an education that draws on the knowledge of the community. Literate young men and women in the community were selected and trained for 6 months to become Barefoot Teachers.

By improving the learning environment of the night schools, by providing drinking water through rain water harvesting, or by providing solar lighting instead of kerosene lamps, and giving a sense of security, mothers started to send their girls to school for the first time.

Since 1975, over 50,000 children have studied at these Night Schools -- and the concept of the Night Schools has been replicated in other states in India.

Join the children at Night School >

The schools are administered by the Village Education Committees. Each Committee has an average membership of 15-30 villagers including 5-10 women. The Committees have their bank accounts at the nearest rural bank. Two of its members along with one member from the College staff operate bank accounts. The Committees are responsible for day-to-day administration of the 250 night schools, purchase of teaching/learning material, repairs and maintenance of night school buildings and disbursement of honorariums to night school teachers.

The Children's Parliament controls and supervises the night schools. It is based on the belief that giving power to the people who have a vested interest in the school is the best way of ensuring its success -- as well as making the children aware of political structure and processes.

The Children's Parliament since its inception in 1993, has had five terms of office. The Parliament has elected representatives from night schools, situated in four districts of Rajasthan, covering a geographical outspread of 700-800 square kilometres, from semi-arid to the desert regions.

Most of the Prime Ministers have been girls, simply because more girls attend the Night Schools than boys.


Meet Bhagchand Dev, one of the former Prime Ministers of the Children's Parliament >

Bhagchand Dev, Women of Tilonia

Furniture

The Tilonia chair originates in Saharanpur in Uttar Pradesh. The traditional design was streamlined and enhanced with an embroidered leather back by Tilonia in 1982. Local carpenters were trained to produce the chair and the side tables in sheesham and babool wood. Traditional peedas, or stools, are also made in Tilonia with either embroidered leather or woven seats. Furniture is available only to wholesale buyers due to shipping requirements.

Train Barefoot Teachers for Night Schools

The majority of rural children in India do not have the time to attend school in the morning. They help their families by tending farm animals, fetching drinking water, collecting firewood. The night schools were started in 1975 to provide a learning environment for these children. Since 1975, over 50,000 children have attended the Barefoot College's night schools.

Barefoot College DVDs, The Ordinary Heroes of Afghanistan, Barefoot Solar Engineers, solar power, rural development, sustainable development documentaries, India development, the Barefoot College of Tilonia, Rajasthan, India

Barefoot solar engineers bring light to remote, poor villages all over the world.

This short film documents the remarkable story of 10 Afghan men and women who travel to the Barefoot College of Tilonia in India to become Barefoot Solar Engineers.

Operating with the conviction that "experts" don't have all the answers and that technology can be demystified, The Barefoot College applies entrepreneurial creativity to the most complex development problems, yielding extraordinary results. The Barefoot College has already trained semi-literate Barefoot professionals to solar electrify over 200 remote communities across India and is now training Barefoot Solar Engineers in 9 developing countries around the world, including Afghanistan.

As documented in The Ordinary Heroes of Afghanistan, the Barefoot College organized five remote Afghani villages to select 10 representatives to become Barefoot Solar Engineers, brought them to India for six months of training, and purchased and transported solar panels to solar electrify the villages for five years, all for less than the cost of hiring one UN or World Bank Consultant in Kabul for one year.

The Ordinary Heroes of Afghanistan was produced by the Barefoot College and Roughcut Productions with support from a Skoll Foundation grant.
(DVD, 20 minutes, 2006)

Visit the Barefoot College website to learn more about barefoot sustainable development >

Tilonia Home: Belle Isle Featherweight Queen Quilt

Jaipuri "razai" are quilts characterized by their feather-weight lightness and warmth. They are made of hand blockprinted cotton voile fabric, filled with finely combed cotton and hand quilted in a close running stitch. A double razai contains 1500 grams of cotton. The Barefoot College and its affiliates work with women in Radoli in Jaipur district, and Kishangarh and Harmara in Ajmer district of Rajasthan who make these quilts.

Please note that these items are produced from handprinted, handloomed cotton so there may be some variation in color and pattern.

In desert regions where wells have gone dry, the only long term cost-effective solution for providing water for drinking and sanitation, is to collect rainwater from the rooftops. Rain is funneled from school rooftops into water-proofed underground tanks. Rainwater can be collected at 10 cents per liter. For the cost of one drilling rig to futilely dig deeper and deeper wells, it is possible to collect 12 million liters of rainwater in 100 schools and give employment to 1000 people for 4 months.

You will help build rainwater harvesting systems in schools in rural areas.

An Avani spinner uses a drop spindle to twist yarn for weaving. Spinning and weaving natural fibers like Tibetan wool and pashmina are traditional skills in the Kumaon region of the Himalayas where Avani is based.

Avani has introduced the spinning and weaving of wild silks like eri, muga and oak tussar as well as mulberry silk in this area.

Solar powered spinning wheels have been developed that are being used by a few spinners in unelectrified villages. Avani has also introduced frame looms with wider widths for handweaving. This has enables a wider product range than possible on the narrower pit looms which have traditionally been used.
Handloomed Shawls, Scarves & Throws

Our handloomed shawls and throws are made from yarns that are handspun and naturally dyed by artisans in the Kumaon Himalayas. More than 350 families of weavers, spinners and knitters work with Avani, a non-profit, community-based organization near Tripuradevi, a village in Kumaon, Uttaranchal, to develop and market their products. Avani yarns are handspun from Tibetan sheep wool, pashmina or wild silks such as tussar, eri and muga. Avani shawls, scarves and throws are pure wool, pure silk or blends of wool and silk.

King size bedspread in Tropical Blue Floral pattern, block printed natural cotton fabric.
100% cotton, 108" x 90"
AZO free dye

These Indian bedspreads are also great for outdoor use as a colorful picnic cloth at the beach or the park for summer fun.

Please note that these bedcovers are very simple, but delightful handcrafted items. They are not lined or padded and are a single fabric layer. They are handprinted on cotton fabric so there may be some variation in color and pattern.

Decorative pillows 16 x 16 are also available and sold separately.

Tilonia Home: King Bedspread - Yellow & Red Stripe Barefoot Handloom
bedspread, cotton bedding, handwoven cotton bedding, handloomed, handwoven textiles, India, Tilonia, Barefoot College, rural artisans, Indian weavers, fair trade

Cheerful yellow and red stripes in handloomed cotton make this king bedspread as vibrant as a breezy summer day. This single layer of casual, colorful cotton fabric is great as a bedspread for summer cottages or a playful picnic blanket for the beach.

100% cotton handwoven by weavers of the Barefoot College, Tilonia. King size 108" x 90"
Machine washable. Wash in cold water to preserve color.

Fabric is handwoven and may have small variations in texture or weave - all part of the charm of an artisan-made bedspread from Tilonia.

Tilonia Home: Table Linens - Blue & Red Floral
napkins, table cloth, tablecloths, table linens

Tilonia Home offers an array of colorful, blockprinted table linens. Table cloth and napkin sets are sized for informal dinner parties of 4, 6 and 8. Matching kitchen apron and oven mitten sets are also available. Pick your pattern, pick your party size -- and enjoy the easy care and informality of these machine washable, 100% cotton table linens. AZO free dyes.

Please note that these items are produced from handprinted cotton so there may be some variation in color and pattern.
indian block print, table linens, placemat, napkins, cotton

Barefoot handloom textiles are produced by 18 weavers of the Gramin Hastshlip Vikas Society, the weavers' association based in Tilonia.

Above, Mohamed Hussein is the son of master weaver Jordan who has been working in Tilonia since 1979. Jordan has been a master weaver for more than 30 years.

Below, yarn is reeled onto bobbins for weaving. Yarn is reeled by hand.



Dye is measured and mixed for dying the cotton yarn used to weave the handloomed fabric.
napkins, tablecloth, table cloth, table cloths, blockprint table cloth,

Festive stripes and plaids in handloomed cotton make these cheerful cotton table linens fun for summer. Weavers at the Barefoot College in Tilonia create the handloomed textiles.

Table linens in Barefoot Handloom include setting for 6 with tablecloth 60" x 90" and 6 napkins 18" x 18". Easy care cotton is machine washable in cold water to preserve color. AZO free dyes.

Biddam Devi cuts blockprint fabric for applique in the production center in Tilonia. An experienced seamstress, Biddam has more than 20 years experience producing Tilonia handcrafted appliques.


Barmer applique was traditionally sewn on bedspreads of black or brown bases. Motifs were almost entirely The Barefoot College works with women in six villages in Rajasthan to produce these appliques. Tilonia applique, the style of applique taught to women by the The Barefoot College, uses designs adapted from mandanas which are traditional patterns on floors in Rajasthan. Abstract motifs are cut from fabrics and then stitched onto the base. An elaborate bedspread may take nearly a month to complete.

Crafty characters for playtime on rainy days!

Ready, Set, Go!
wrap, scarf, shawl, shawls, silk wrap, silk shawls, evening wraps, silk wraps, mufflers, muffler

Ready, Set, Go on a Weekend Away. Tilonia's Travel & Spa collection includes blockprinted beach mats, cosmetic bags and travel bags that are perfect for weekend trips to the country, a day at the beach or a trip to the gym. Add a bright and colorful tiedyed wrap for an eye-catching accessory. As the sun sets wrap yourself in elegant Avani silk shawls that transition perfectly from day into night. Pamper yourself in these shimmering soft silk shawls, handwoven and naturally dyed by rural artisans in the Himalayas.

Barefoot handloom textiles are produced by 18 weavers of the Gramin Hastshlip Vikas Society, the weavers' association based in Tilonia.

Above, Mohamed Hussein is the son of master weaver Jordan who has been working in Tilonia since 1979. Jordan has been a master weaver for more than 30 years. Below, yarn is reeled onto bobbins for weaving.

Below, yarn is reeled by hand. Dye is measured and mixed for dying the cotton yarn used to weave the handloomed fabric.
Barefoot Handloom
cotton textiles, handwoven textiles, weavers, bags, bedding, table linens, fair trade, Rajasthan

Weaving was traditionally a scheduled cast occupation restricted to a community called Balais or Meghwals. These communities used pit looms that produced a 24" width fabric. Handlooms were introduced as they produced fabric wider than than the pit looms, and thus were more efficient. With the change in looms, people from all communities became weavers as the caste associations of pitloom weaving were removed. There is also a group of Rajput women from the village of Kada who have broken tradition to learn how to weave.

All Tilonia Barefoot Handloom products are dyed, woven and stitched on campus at the Barefoot College campus in Tilonia, Rajasthan, India.

Our Partnership with Our Trade Affiliates

You are our partner in helping to improve the livelihoods of rural artisans in India. As a retail or design professional, you are invited to join our Trade Affiliate program.

As a qualified trade affiliate, you will enjoy these benefits when you place your order online through our Trade Affiliate section:

  • A trade discount on standard stock items when you meet our minimum purchase requirement.
  • Seasonal product previews
  • Special offers for the trade only
Additional benefits are available if you participate as a Trade Affiliate in our Cooperative Buying program. By making an annual purchase commitment to our artisan affiliates, you also receive:
  • An additional 10% discount when you place your order online for our pre-production promotions with no minimum purchase required on individual orders.
  • No restocking fees for Trade Affiliates who participate in our Cooperative Buying program.

If you are a retail or design professional interested in presenting Tilonia products to your clients, please contact us at shop@tilonia.com.

This is the wholesale text box

Just in time for spring decorating, Barefoot Handloom Bedspreads are a simple way to add warm and cheerful color to your home.

The Barefoot Handloom Collection of hand-woven bedspreads are produced by 18 weavers of the Gramin Hastship Vikas Society, the weaver's association based at the Barefoot College in Tilonia, Rajasthan, India. Three women are members of the association.

Yarn is reeled by hand. Dye is measured and mixed for dyeing the cotton yarn used to weave the handloomed fabric

If you are a retailer interested in carrying Tilonia products in your store, please contact us at shop@tilonia.com.

Tilonia brings the color and spice of the Indian village to the modern home with fairly traded home textiles that empower rural artisans.Select from a wide variety of Indian bedspreads. Whether you prefer simple geometric patterns, or more elegant floral patterns, these colorful Indian bedspreads are great when you want to decorate a vacation house or a college dorm -- without spending a fortune. These bedspreads are a light-weight cotton muslin and perfect for an easy care cover in a casual setting. They are also great for outdoor use as a colorful picnic cloth at the beach or the park for summer fun.

Available in King, Queen and Twin sizes
Pillow cover sizes available are: Queen, King, standard sham 20" x 30" and accent pillow 16"x16".
The Women of Tilonia: Portraits of Change
The Women of Tilonia: Portraits of Change

Barefoot College movies, DVDs, Women of Tilonia: Portraits of Chance, Barefoot Women of Tilonia, women's rights, rural development, sustainable development documentaries, Barefoot College of Tilonia, purdah, Indian women

This interactive DVD presents the personal stories of 22 women of Tilonia. Each woman tells her own personal story. Each profile is one of courage, telling of her strength and determination to become more than her family or traditional community expected of them.

The Women of Tilonia: Portraits of Change was produced by the Barefoot College.
(DVD, 2006)
